dt: {bc}any of a family (Charadriidae) of shorebirds that differ from the sandpipers in having a short hard-tipped bill and usually a stouter more compact build
{bc}any of various birds (such as a turnstone or sandpiper) related to the {a_link|plovers}

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}plover, pluvier{/it}, from Vulgar Latin {it}*pluviarius{/it}, from Latin {it}pluvia{/it} rain {ma}{mat|pluvial|}{/ma}
shortdef: any of a family (Charadriidae) of shorebirds that differ from the sandpipers in having a short hard-tipped bill and usually a stouter more compact build
any of various birds (such as a turnstone or sandpiper) related to the plovers

dt: {bc}any of three plovers (genus {it}Pluvialis{/it}) having dark upperparts spotted with gold
{bc}one ({it}P. dominica{/it}) that breeds chiefly in arctic America and winters in South America

shortdef: any of three plovers (genus Pluvialis) having dark upperparts spotted with gold; especially : one (P. dominica) that breeds chiefly in arctic America and winters in South America

dt: {bc}a small pale plover ({it}Charadrius melodus{/it}) chiefly of eastern North America

shortdef: a small pale plover (Charadrius melodus) chiefly of eastern North America

dt: {bc}a small plover ({it}Charadrius alexandrinus{/it}) of the Gulf coast and the eastern U.S. and Mexico that is light gray above with a black bill, black patches on the head and sides of the neck, and white underparts

shortdef: a small plover (Charadrius alexandrinus) of the Gulf coast and the eastern U.S. and Mexico that is light gray above with a black bill, black patches on the head and sides of the neck, and white underparts
